def sub(self, repl, /, *, max_depth=1, star=0, denominator_method='lcm') 
704    def sub(self, repl, /, *, max_depth=1, star=0, denominator_method='lcm'):
705        """Changes outcomes of the die to other outcomes.
706
707        You can think of this as `sub`stituting outcomes of this die for other
708        outcomes or dice. Or, as executing a `sub`routine based on the roll of
709        this die.
710
711        Args:
712            repl: One of the following:
713                * A map from old outcomes to new outcomes.
714                    Unmapped old outcomes stay the same.
715                * A callable mapping old outcomes to new outcomes.
716                The new outcomes may be dice rather than just single outcomes.
717                The special value `icepool.Reroll` will reroll that old outcome.
718            max_depth: `sub()` will be repeated with the same argument on the
719                result this many times. If set to `None`, this will repeat until
720                a fixed point is reached.
721            star: If set to `True` or 1, outcomes will be unpacked as
722                `*outcome` before giving it to the `repl` function. If `repl`
723                is not a callable, this has no effect.
724            denominator_method: As `icepool.Die()`.
725
726        Returns:
727            The relabeled die.
728        """
729        if max_depth == 0:
730            return self
731        elif max_depth == 1:
732            if hasattr(repl, 'items'):
733                repl = [(repl[outcome] if outcome in repl else outcome)
734                        for outcome in self.outcomes()]
735            elif callable(repl):
736                if star:
737                    repl = [repl(*outcome) for outcome in self.outcomes()]
738                else:
739                    repl = [repl(outcome) for outcome in self.outcomes()]
740
741            return icepool.Die(*repl,
742                               weights=self.weights(),
743                               denominator_method=denominator_method)
744        elif max_depth is not None:
745            next = self.sub(repl,
746                            max_depth=1,
747                            denominator_method=denominator_method)
748            return next.sub(repl,
749                            max_depth=max_depth - 1,
750                            denominator_method=denominator_method)
751        else:
752            # Seek fixed point.
753            next = self.sub(repl,
754                            max_depth=1,
755                            denominator_method=denominator_method)
756            if self.reduce_weights().equals(next.reduce_weights()):
757                return self
758            else:
759                return next.sub(repl,
760                                max_depth=None,
761                                denominator_method=denominator_method)

Changes outcomes of the die to other outcomes.

You can think of this as substituting outcomes of this die for other outcomes or dice. Or, as executing a subroutine based on the roll of this die.

Args
  • repl: One of the following:
    • A map from old outcomes to new outcomes. Unmapped old outcomes stay the same.
    • A callable mapping old outcomes to new outcomes. The new outcomes may be dice rather than just single outcomes. The special value icepool.Reroll will reroll that old outcome.
  • max_depth: sub() will be repeated with the same argument on the result this many times. If set to None, this will repeat until a fixed point is reached.
  • star: If set to True or 1, outcomes will be unpacked as *outcome before giving it to the repl function. If repl is not a callable, this has no effect.
  • denominator_method: As icepool.Die().
Returns

The relabeled die.

def explode(self, outcomes=None, *, max_depth=None, star=0) 
763    def explode(self, outcomes=None, *, max_depth=None, star=0):
764        """Causes outcomes to be rolled again and added to the total.
765
766        Args:
767            outcomes: Which outcomes to explode. Options:
768                * An iterable containing outcomes to explode.
769                * A callable that takes an outcome and returns `True` if it
770                    should be exploded.
771                * If not supplied, the max outcome will explode.
772            max_depth: The maximum number of additional dice to roll.
773                If not supplied, a default value will be used.
774            star: If set to `True` or 1, outcomes will be unpacked as
775                `*outcome` before giving it to the `outcomes` function.
776                If `outcomes` is not a callable, this has no effect.
777        """
778        if outcomes is None:
779            outcomes = {self.max_outcome()}
780        elif callable(outcomes):
781            if star:
782                outcomes = {
783                    outcome for outcome in self.outcomes() if outcomes(*outcome)
784                }
785            else:
786                outcomes = {
787                    outcome for outcome in self.outcomes() if outcomes(outcome)
788                }
789
790        if len(outcomes) == 0:
791            return self
792
793        if max_depth is None:
794            max_depth = 9
795        elif max_depth < 0:
796            raise ValueError('max_depth cannot be negative.')
797        elif max_depth == 0:
798            return self
799
800        tail_die = self.explode(outcomes=outcomes, max_depth=max_depth - 1)
801
802        def sub_func(outcome):
803            if outcome in outcomes:
804                return outcome + tail_die
805            else:
806                return outcome
807
808        return self.sub(sub_func, denominator_method='lcm')

Causes outcomes to be rolled again and added to the total.

Args
  • outcomes: Which outcomes to explode. Options:
    • An iterable containing outcomes to explode.
    • A callable that takes an outcome and returns True if it should be exploded.
    • If not supplied, the max outcome will explode.
  • max_depth: The maximum number of additional dice to roll. If not supplied, a default value will be used.
  • star: If set to True or 1, outcomes will be unpacked as *outcome before giving it to the outcomes function. If outcomes is not a callable, this has no effect.
def if_else( self, outcome_if_true, outcome_if_false, /, *, denominator_method='lcm') 
810    def if_else(self,
811                outcome_if_true,
812                outcome_if_false,
813                /,
814                *,
815                denominator_method='lcm'):
816        """Ternary conditional operator.
817
818        This replaces truthy outcomes with the first argument and falsy outcomes
819        with the second argument.
820        """
821        return self.bool().sub(lambda x: outcome_if_true
822                               if x else outcome_if_false,
823                               denominator_method=denominator_method)

Ternary conditional operator.

This replaces truthy outcomes with the first argument and falsy outcomes with the second argument.

def lowest(*dice) 
827    def lowest(*dice):
828        """Roll all the dice and take the lowest.
829
830        The maximum outcome is equal to the least maximum outcome among all
831        input dice.
832        """
833        dice = [Die(die) for die in dice]
834        max_outcome = min(die.max_outcome() for die in dice)
835        dice = [die.clip(max_outcome=max_outcome) for die in dice]
836        dice = icepool.align(*dice)
837        sweights = tuple(
838            math.prod(t) for t in zip(*(die.sweights() for die in dice)))
839        return icepool.from_sweights(dice[0].outcomes(), sweights)

def repeat_and_sum(self, num_dice) 
859    def repeat_and_sum(self, num_dice):
860        """Roll this die `num_dice` times and sum the results.
861
862        If `num_dice` is negative, roll the die `abs(num_dice)` times and negate
863        the result.
864        """
865        if num_dice in self._repeat_and_sum_cache:
866            return self._repeat_and_sum_cache[num_dice]
867
868        if num_dice < 0:
869            result = -self.repeat_and_sum(-num_dice)
870        elif num_dice == 0:
871            result = self.zero()
872        elif num_dice == 1:
873            result = self
874        else:
875            # Binary split seems to perform much worse.
876            result = self + self.repeat_and_sum(num_dice - 1)
877
878        self._repeat_and_sum_cache[num_dice] = result
879        return result

Roll this die num_dice times and sum the results.

If num_dice is negative, roll the die abs(num_dice) times and negate the result.

def d(self, other) 
881    def d(self, other):
882        """Roll the left die, then roll the right die that many times and sum the outcomes.
883
884        If an `int` is provided for the right side, it becomes a standard die
885        with that many faces. Otherwise it is converted to a die.
886        """
887        if isinstance(other, int):
888            other = icepool.standard(other)
889        else:
890            other = icepool.Die(other)
891
892        data = defaultdict(int)
893
894        max_abs_die_count = max(abs(self.min_outcome()),
895                                abs(self.max_outcome()))
896        for die_count, die_count_weight in self.items():
897            factor = other.denominator()**(max_abs_die_count - abs(die_count))
898            subresult = other.repeat_and_sum(die_count)
899            for outcome, subresult_weight in subresult.items():
900                data[outcome] += subresult_weight * die_count_weight * factor
901
902        return icepool.Die(data)

Roll the left die, then roll the right die that many times and sum the outcomes.

If an int is provided for the right side, it becomes a standard die with that many faces. Otherwise it is converted to a die.

def keep( self, num_dice=None, count_dice=None, *, truncate_min=None, truncate_max=None) 
908    def keep(self,
909             num_dice=None,
910             count_dice=None,
911             *,
912             truncate_min=None,
913             truncate_max=None):
914        """Roll several of this die and sum some or all of the sorted results.
915
916        Args:
917            num_dice: The number of dice to roll. All dice will have the same
918                outcomes as `self`.
919            count_dice: Only dice selected by this will be counted.
920                See `Pool.count_dice()` for details.
921            truncate_min: A sequence of one outcome per die.
922                That die will be truncated to that minimum outcome, with all
923                lower outcomes being removed (i.e. rerolled).
924                This is not compatible with `truncate_max`.
925            truncate_max: A sequence of one outcome per die.
926                That die will be truncated to that maximum outcome, with all
927                higher outcomes being removed (i.e. rerolled).
928                This is not compatible with `truncate_min`.

931            A Die representing the probability distribution of the sum.
932        """

934                            num_dice,
935                            count_dice=count_dice,
936                            truncate_min=truncate_min,
937                            truncate_max=truncate_max)
938        if isinstance(count_dice, int):
939            return pool
940        else:
941            return pool.sum()

1072        """Zeros all outcomes of this die.
1073

1075        arguments.
1076

def equals(self, other, *, reduce=False) 
1344    def equals(self, other, *, reduce=False):
1345        """Returns `True` iff both dice have the same outcomes and weights.
1346
1347        Truth value does NOT matter.
1348
1349        If one die has a zero-weight outcome and the other die does not contain
1350        that outcome, they are treated as unequal by this function.
1351
1352        The `==` and `!=` operators have a dual purpose; they return a die
1353        representing the result of the operator as normal,
1354        but the die additionally has a truth value determined by this method.
1355        Only dice returned by these methods have a truth value.
1356
1357        Args:
1358            reduce: If `True`, the dice will be reduced before comparing.
1359                Otherwise, e.g. a 2:2 coin is not `equals()` to a 1:1 coin.
1360        """
1361        try:
1362            other = icepool.Die(other)
1363        except ValueError:
1364            return False
1365
1366        if reduce:
1367            return self.reduce_weights().key_tuple() == other.reduce_weights(
1368            ).key_tuple()
1369        else:
1370            return self.key_tuple() == other.key_tuple()

Returns True iff both dice have the same outcomes and weights.

Truth value does NOT matter.

If one die has a zero-weight outcome and the other die does not contain that outcome, they are treated as unequal by this function.

The == and != operators have a dual purpose; they return a die representing the result of the operator as normal, but the die additionally has a truth value determined by this method. Only dice returned by these methods have a truth value.

Args
  • reduce: If True, the dice will be reduced before comparing. Otherwise, e.g. a 2:2 coin is not equals() to a 1:1 coin.

def from_cweights(outcomes, cweights) 
89def from_cweights(outcomes, cweights):
90    """Constructs a die from cumulative weights. """
91    prev = 0
92    d = {}
93    for outcome, weight in zip(outcomes, cweights):
94        d[outcome] = weight - prev
95        prev = weight
96    return icepool.Die(d)

Constructs a die from cumulative weights.

def from_sweights(outcomes, sweights) 
 99def from_sweights(outcomes, sweights):
100    """Constructs a die from survival weights. """
101    prev = 0
102    d = {}
103    for outcome, weight in zip(reversed(outcomes), reversed(tuple(sweights))):
104        d[outcome] = weight - prev
105        prev = weight
106    return icepool.Die(d)

Constructs a die from survival weights.

def from_rv(rv, outcomes, denominator, **kwargs) 
109def from_rv(rv, outcomes, denominator, **kwargs):
110    """Constructs a die from a rv object (as `scipy.stats`).
111    Args:
112        rv: A rv object (as `scipy.stats`).
113        outcomes: An iterable of `int`s or `float`s that will be the outcomes
114            of the resulting die.
115            If the distribution is discrete, outcomes must be `int`s.
116        denominator: The denominator of the resulting die will be set to this.
117        **kwargs: These will be provided to `rv.cdf()`.
118    """
119    if hasattr(rv, 'pdf'):
120        # Continuous distributions use midpoints.
121        midpoints = [(a + b) / 2 for a, b in zip(outcomes[:-1], outcomes[1:])]
122        cdf = rv.cdf(midpoints, **kwargs)
123        cweights = tuple(
124            int(round(x * denominator)) for x in cdf) + (denominator,)
125    else:
126        cdf = rv.cdf(outcomes, **kwargs)
127        cweights = tuple(int(round(x * denominator)) for x in cdf)
128    return from_cweights(outcomes, cweights)

Constructs a die from a rv object (as scipy.stats).

Args
  • rv: A rv object (as scipy.stats).
  • outcomes: An iterable of ints or floats that will be the outcomes of the resulting die. If the distribution is discrete, outcomes must be ints.
  • denominator: The denominator of the resulting die will be set to this.
  • **kwargs: These will be provided to rv.cdf().
def align(*dice) 
131def align(*dice):
132    """Pads dice with zero weights so that all have the same set of outcomes.
133
134    Args:
135        *dice: One die per argument.
136
137    Returns:
138        A tuple of aligned dice.
139    """
140    dice = [icepool.Die(die) for die in dice]
141    outcomes = set(itertools.chain.from_iterable(
142        die.outcomes() for die in dice))
143    return tuple(die.set_outcomes(outcomes) for die in dice)

def reduce(func, dice, *, initial=None) 
162def reduce(func, dice, *, initial=None):
163    """Applies a function of two arguments cumulatively to a sequence of dice.
164
165    Analogous to
166    [`functools.reduce()`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functools.html#functools.reduce).
167
168    The function is applied non-elementwise to tuple outcomes.
169
170    Args:
171        func: The function to apply. The function should take two arguments,
172            which are an outcome from each of two dice.
173        dice: A sequence of dice to apply the function to, from left to right.
174        initial: If provided, this will be placed at the front of the sequence
175            of dice.
176    """
177    # Conversion to dice is not necessary since apply() takes care of that.
178    iter_dice = iter(dice)
179    if initial is not None:
180        result = initial
181    else:
182        result = next(iter_dice)
183    for die in iter_dice:
184        result = apply(func, result, die)
185    return result

Applies a function of two arguments cumulatively to a sequence of dice.

Analogous to functools.reduce().

The function is applied non-elementwise to tuple outcomes.

Args
  • func: The function to apply. The function should take two arguments, which are an outcome from each of two dice.
  • dice: A sequence of dice to apply the function to, from left to right.
  • initial: If provided, this will be placed at the front of the sequence of dice.
def accumulate(func, dice, *, initial=None) 
188def accumulate(func, dice, *, initial=None):
189    """Applies a function of two arguments cumulatively to a sequence of dice, yielding each result in turn.
190
191    Analogous to
192    [`itertools.accumulate()`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/itertools.html#itertools.accumulate)
193    , though with no default function and
194    the same parameter order as `reduce()`.
195
196    The number of results is equal to the number of elements of `dice`, with
197    one additional element if `initial` is provided.
198
199    The function is applied non-elementwise to tuple outcomes.
200
201    Args:
202        func: The function to apply. The function should take two arguments,
203            which are an outcome from each of two dice.
204        dice: A sequence of dice to apply the function to, from left to right.
205        initial: If provided, this will be placed at the front of the sequence
206            of dice.
207    """
208    # Conversion to dice is not necessary since apply() takes care of that.
209    iter_dice = iter(dice)
210    if initial is not None:
211        result = initial
212    else:
213        try:
214            result = next(iter_dice)
215        except StopIteration:
216            return
217    yield result
218    for die in iter_dice:
219        result = apply(func, result, die)
220        yield result

Applies a function of two arguments cumulatively to a sequence of dice, yielding each result in turn.

Analogous to itertools.accumulate() , though with no default function and the same parameter order as reduce().

The number of results is equal to the number of elements of dice, with one additional element if initial is provided.

The function is applied non-elementwise to tuple outcomes.

Args
  • func: The function to apply. The function should take two arguments, which are an outcome from each of two dice.
  • dice: A sequence of dice to apply the function to, from left to right.
  • initial: If provided, this will be placed at the front of the sequence of dice.
def apply(func, *dice) 
223def apply(func, *dice):
224    """Applies `func(outcome_of_die_0, outcome_of_die_1, ...)` for all possible outcomes of the dice.
225
226    Example: `apply(lambda a, b: a + b, d6, d6)` is the same as d6 + d6.
227
228    `apply()` is flexible but not very efficient for more than two dice.
229    Instead of using a large number of arguments:
230    * If the problem is easy to solve by considering one additional die at a
231        time, try using `reduce()` instead.
232    * If the problem is easy to solve by considering how many dice rolled each
233        outcome, one outcome at a time, try using
234        `icepool.Pool` and `icepool.EvalPool`.
235
236    Args:
237        func: A function that takes one argument per input die and returns an
238            argument to `Die()`.
239        *dice: Any number of dice (or objects convertible to dice).
240            `func` will be called with all possible joint outcomes of `dice`,
241            with one argument per die.
242
243    Returns:
244        A die constructed from the outputs of `func` and the product of the
245        weights of the dice.
246    """
247    if len(dice) == 0:
248        return icepool.Die()
249    dice = [icepool.Die(die) for die in dice]
250    final_outcomes = []
251    final_weights = []
252    for t in itertools.product(*(die.items() for die in dice)):
253        outcomes, weights = zip(*t)
254        final_outcome = func(*outcomes)
255        final_weight = math.prod(weights)
256        if final_outcome is not icepool.Reroll:
257            final_outcomes.append(final_outcome)
258            final_weights.append(final_weight)
259
260    return icepool.Die(*final_outcomes, weights=final_weights)

Applies func(outcome_of_die_0, outcome_of_die_1, ...) for all possible outcomes of the dice.

Example: apply(lambda a, b: a + b, d6, d6) is the same as d6 + d6.

apply() is flexible but not very efficient for more than two dice. Instead of using a large number of arguments:

  • If the problem is easy to solve by considering one additional die at a time, try using reduce() instead.
  • If the problem is easy to solve by considering how many dice rolled each outcome, one outcome at a time, try using icepool.Pool and icepool.EvalPool.
Args
  • func: A function that takes one argument per input die and returns an argument to Die().
  • *dice: Any number of dice (or objects convertible to dice). func will be called with all possible joint outcomes of dice, with one argument per die.
Returns

A die constructed from the outputs of func and the product of the weights of the dice.

Reroll = <SpecialValue.Reroll: 'Reroll'>

Indicates an outcome should be rerolled (with no max depth).

class PoolBase(abc.ABC): 
  9class PoolBase(ABC):
 10    """Abstract base class for dice pools.
 11
 12    This provides the methods needed to run the dice pool algorithm.
 13
 14    There are two subclasses:
 15
 16    * `Pool`, which represents a pool of dice with random results.
 17    * `PoolRoll`, which represents a single, fixed roll of a pool.
 18        `PoolRoll` is only needed internally, as external dicts and sequences
 19        will be implicitly converted to `PoolRoll` in `EvalPool.eval()`.
 20    """
 21
 22    @abstractmethod
 23    def _is_single_roll(self):
 24        """Returns `True` iff this is a single, fixed roll of a pool. """
 25
 26    @abstractmethod
 27    def _has_truncate_min(self):
 28        """Returns `True` iff the pool has truncated min outcomes. """
 29
 30    @abstractmethod
 31    def _has_truncate_max(self):
 32        """Returns `True` iff the pool has truncated max outcomes. """
 33
 34    @abstractmethod
 35    def outcomes(self):
 36        """The outcomes of the fundamental die (including those with zero weight). """
 37
 38    @abstractmethod
 39    def _min_outcome(self):
 40        """The minimum outcome of the fundamental die. """
 41
 42    @abstractmethod
 43    def _max_outcome(self):
 44        """The maximum outcome of the fundamental die. """
 45
 46    @abstractmethod
 47    def _direction_score_ascending(self):
 48        """Returns a number indicating how preferred iterating in the ascending direction is.
 49
 50        This is only called when there is no truncation.
 51
 52        If the pool does not care at all about direction, the result is 0.
 53
 54        The collective score is summed.
 55        """
 56
 57    @abstractmethod
 58    def _direction_score_descending(self):
 59        """Returns a number indicating how preferred iterating in the descending direction is.
 60
 61        This is only called when there is no truncation.
 62
 63        If the pool does not care at all about direction, the result is 0.
 64
 65        The collective score is summed.
 66        """
 67
 68    @abstractmethod
 69    def _pop_min(self):
 70        """Returns a sequence of pool, count, weight corresponding to removing
 71        the min outcome, with count and weight corresponding to various numbers
 72        of dice rolling that outcome.
 73        """
 74
 75    @abstractmethod
 76    def _pop_max(self):
 77        """Returns a sequence of pool, count, weight corresponding to removing
 78        the max outcome, with count and weight corresponding to various numbers
 79        of dice rolling that outcome.
 80        """
 81
 82    def eval(self, eval_or_func, /):
 83        """Evaluates this pool using the given `EvalPool` or function.
 84
 85        Note that each `EvalPool` instance carries its own cache;
 86        if you plan to use an evaluation multiple times,
 87        you may want to explicitly create an `EvalPool` instance
 88        rather than passing a function to this method directly.
 89
 90        Args:
 91            func: This can be an `EvalPool`, in which case it evaluates the pool
 92                directly. Or it can be a `EvalPool.next_state()`-like function,
 93                taking in `state, outcome, *counts` and returning the next state.
 94                In this case a temporary `WrapFuncEval` is constructed and used
 95                to evaluate this pool.
 96        """
 97        if not isinstance(eval_or_func, icepool.EvalPool):
 98            eval_or_func = icepool.WrapFuncEval(eval_or_func)
 99        return eval_or_func.eval(self)
100
101    def sum(self):
102        """Convenience method to simply sum the dice in this pool.
103
104        This uses `icepool.sum_pool`.
105
106        Returns:
107            A die representing the sum.
108        """
109        return icepool.sum_pool(self)

Abstract base class for dice pools.

This provides the methods needed to run the dice pool algorithm.

There are two subclasses:

  • Pool, which represents a pool of dice with random results.
  • PoolRoll, which represents a single, fixed roll of a pool. PoolRoll is only needed internally, as external dicts and sequences will be implicitly converted to PoolRoll in EvalPool.eval().

class Pool(icepool.PoolBase): 
183class Pool(icepool.PoolBase):
184    """Represents set of (mostly) indistiguishable dice.
185
186    This should be used in conjunction with `EvalPool` to generate a result.
187
188    A pool is defined by:
189
190    * A fundamental die.
191    * The number of dice in the pool.
192    * Which of the sorted positions are counted (possibly multiple or negative
193        times).
194    * Possibly truncating the max or min outcomes of dice in the pool
195        (but not both) relative to the fundamental die.
196    """
197
198    def __new__(cls,
199                die,
200                num_dice=None,
201                count_dice=None,
202                *,
203                truncate_min=None,
204                truncate_max=None):
205        """Constructor for a pool.
206
207        You can use `die.pool(num_dice=None, ...)` for the same effect as this.
208
209        All instances are cached. The members of the actual instance may not match
210        the arguments exactly; instead, they may be optimized to values that give
211        the same result as far as `EvalPool` is concerned.
212
213        Args:
214            die: The fundamental die of the pool.
215                If outcomes are not reachable by any die due to `truncate_min` or
216                `truncate_max`, they will have 0 count. Zero-weight outcomes will
217                appear with zero weight, but can still generate nonzero counts.
218            num_dice: An `int` that sets the number of dice in the pool.
219                If not provided, the number of dice will be inferred from the other
220                arguments. If no arguments are provided at all, this defaults to 0.
221            count_dice: Determines which of the **sorted** dice will be counted,
222                and how many times. Prefer to use the `Pool`'s `[]` operator
223                after the fact rather than providing an argument here.
224                This operator is an alias for `Pool.set_count_dice()`.
225                See that method's docstring for details.
226            truncate_max: A sequence of one outcome per die in the pool.
227                That die will be truncated to that maximum outcome, with all greater
228                outcomes having 0 count. Values cannot be > the `max_outcome` of the
229                fundamental die. A pool cannot have both `truncate_min` and
230                `truncate_max`.This can be used to efficiently roll a set of mixed
231                standard dice. For example,
232                `Pool(icepool.d12, truncate_max=[6, 6, 6, 8, 8])`
233                would be a pool of 3d6 and 2d8.
234            truncate_min: A sequence of one outcome per die in the pool.
235                That die will be truncated to that minimum outcome, with all lesser
236                outcomes having 0 count. Values cannot be < the `min_outcome` of the
237                fundamental die. A pool cannot have both `truncate_min` and
238                `truncate_max`.
239
240        Returns:
241            A `Pool` instance. If `count_dice` is a single `int` index, the
242            result will be a `Die` rather than a `Pool`.
243
244        Raises:
245            `ValueError` if arguments result in a conflicting number of dice,
246            if both `truncate_min` and `truncate_max` are provided,
247            or if truncation would produce an empty die.
248        """
249        die, count_dice, truncate_min, truncate_max, convert_to_die = canonicalize_pool_args(
250            die, num_dice, count_dice, truncate_min, truncate_max)
251
252        self = Pool._pool_cached_unchecked(die, count_dice, truncate_min,
253                                           truncate_max)
254
255        if convert_to_die:
256            return self.eval(lambda state, outcome, count: outcome
257                             if count else state)
258        else:
259            return self
260
261    _instance_cache = {}
262
263    @classmethod
264    def _pool_cached_unchecked(cls,
265                               die,
266                               count_dice,
267                               truncate_min=None,
268                               truncate_max=None):
269        key = (die.key_tuple(), count_dice, truncate_min, truncate_max)
270        if key in Pool._instance_cache:
271            return Pool._instance_cache[key]
272        else:
273            self = super(Pool, cls).__new__(cls)
274            self._die = die
275            self._count_dice = count_dice
276            self._truncate_max = truncate_max
277            self._truncate_min = truncate_min
278            Pool._instance_cache[key] = self
279            return self
280
281    def _is_single_roll(self):
282        return False
283
284    def die(self):
285        """The fundamental die of the pool. """
286        return self._die
287
288    def outcomes(self):
289        return self.die().outcomes()
290
291    def _min_outcome(self):
292        return self.die().min_outcome()
293
294    def _max_outcome(self):
295        return self.die().max_outcome()
296
297    def count_dice(self):
298        """A tuple indicating how many times each of the dice, sorted from lowest to highest, counts. """
299        return self._count_dice
300
301    def num_dice(self):
302        """The number of dice in this pool (before dropping or counting multiple times). """
303        return len(self._count_dice)
304
305    def set_count_dice(self, count_dice):
306        """Returns a pool with the selected dice counted.
307
308        You can use `pool[count_dice]` for the same effect as this method.
309
310        The dice are sorted in ascending order for this purpose,
311        regardless of which order the outcomes are evaluated in.
312
313        This is always an absolute selection on all `num_dice`,
314        not a relative selection on already-selected dice,
315        which would be ambiguous in the presence of multiple or negative counts.
316
317        For example, here are some ways of selecting the two highest dice out of 5:
318
319        * `pool[3:5]`
320        * `pool[3:]`
321        * `pool[-2:]`
322        * `pool[..., 1, 1]`
323
324        These will also select the two highest dice out of 5, and will also
325        resize the pool to 5 dice first:
326
327        * `pool[3::5]`
328        * `pool[3:5:5]`
329        * `pool[-2::5]`
330        * `pool[0, 0, 0, 1, 1]`
331
332        These will count the highest as a positive and the lowest as a negative:
333
334        * `pool[-1, 0, 0, 0, 1]`
335        * `pool[-1, ..., 1]`
336
337        Args:
338            `None`: All dice will be counted once.
339            An `int`. This will count only the die at the specified index (once).
340                In this case, the result will be a die, not a pool.
341            A `slice`. The selected dice are counted once each.
342                If provided, the third argument resizes the pool,
343                rather than being a step,
344                but only if the pool does not have `truncate_max` or `truncate_min`.
345            A sequence of one `int`s for each die.
346                Each die is counted that many times, which could be multiple or
347                negative times. This may resize the pool, but only if the pool
348                does not have `truncate_max` or `truncate_min`.
349
350                Up to one `Ellipsis` (`...`) may be used.
351                If an `Ellipsis` is used, the size of the pool won't change. Instead:
352
353                * If `count_dice` is shorter than `num_dice`, the `Ellipsis`
354                    acts as enough zero counts to make up the difference.
355                    E.g. `pool[1, ..., 1]` on five dice would act as `pool[1, 0, 0, 0, 1]`.
356                * If `count_dice` has length equal to `num_dice`, the `Ellipsis` has no effect.
357                    E.g. `pool[1, ..., 1]` on two dice would act as `pool[1, 1]`.
358                * If `count_dice` is longer than `num_dice` and the `Ellipsis` is on one side,
359                    elements will be dropped from `count_dice` on the side with the `Ellipsis`.
360                    E.g. `pool[..., 1, 2, 3]` on two dice would act as `pool[2, 3]`.
361                * If `count_dice` is longer than `num_dice` and the `Ellipsis`
362                    is in the middle, the counts will be as the sum of two
363                    one-sided `Ellipsis`.
364                    E.g. `pool[-1, ..., 1]` acts like `[-1, ...]` plus `[..., 1]`.
365                    On a pool consisting of a single single die this would have
366                    the -1 and 1 cancel each other out.
367
368        Raises:
369            ValueError:  If `count_dice` would change the size of a pool with
370                `truncate_max` or `truncate_min`, or if more than one `Ellipsis`
371                is used.
372        """
373        convert_to_die = isinstance(count_dice, int)
374        count_dice = count_dice_tuple(self.num_dice(), count_dice)
375        if len(count_dice) != self.num_dice():
376            if self.truncate_max() is not None:
377                raise ValueError(
378                    'Cannot change the size of a pool with truncate_max.')
379            if self.truncate_min() is not None:
380                raise ValueError(
381                    'Cannot change the size of a pool with truncate_min.')
382        result = Pool._pool_cached_unchecked(self.die(),
383                                             count_dice=count_dice,
384                                             truncate_max=self.truncate_max(),
385                                             truncate_min=self.truncate_min())
386        if convert_to_die:
387            return result.eval(lambda state, outcome, count: outcome
388                               if count else state)
389        else:
390            return result
391
392    __getitem__ = set_count_dice
393
394    def __iter__(self):
395        raise TypeError("'Pool' object is not iterable")
396
397    @cached_property
398    def _num_drop_lowest(self):
399        """How many elements of count_dice on the low side are falsy. """
400        for i, count in enumerate(self.count_dice()):
401            if count:
402                return i
403        return self.num_dice()
404
405    def _direction_score_ascending(self):
406        return self._num_drop_lowest * len(self.outcomes())
407
408    @cached_property
409    def _num_drop_highest(self):
410        """How many elements of count_dice on the high side are falsy. """
411        for i, count in enumerate(reversed(self.count_dice())):
412            if count:
413                return i
414        return self.num_dice()
415
416    def _direction_score_descending(self):
417        return self._num_drop_highest * len(self.outcomes())
418
419    def truncate_min(self, always_tuple=False):
420        """A sorted tuple of thresholds below which outcomes are truncated, one for each die in the pool.
421
422        Args:
423            always_tuple: If `False`, this will return `None` if there are no
424                die-specific `truncate_min`. If `True` this will return a
425                `tuple` even in this case.
426        """
427        if self._truncate_min is None and always_tuple:
428            return (self.die().min_outcome(),) * self.num_dice()
429        return self._truncate_min
430
431    def _has_truncate_min(self):
432        return self._truncate_min is not None
433
434    def truncate_max(self, always_tuple=False):
435        """A sorted tuple of thresholds above which outcomes are truncated, one for each die in the pool.
436
437        Args:
438            always_tuple: If `False`, this will return `None` if there are no
439                die-specific `truncate_min`. If `True` this will return a
440                `tuple` even in this case.
441        """
442        if self._truncate_max is None and always_tuple:
443            return (self.die().max_outcome(),) * self.num_dice()
444        return self._truncate_max
445
446    def _has_truncate_max(self):
447        return self._truncate_max is not None
448
449    def _iter_pop_min(self):
450        """
451        Yields:
452            From 0 to the number of dice that can roll this outcome inclusive:
453            * pool: A `Pool` resulting from removing that many dice from
454                this `Pool`, while also removing the min outcome.
455                If there is only one outcome with weight remaining, only one
456                result will be yielded, corresponding to all dice rolling that outcome.
457                If the outcome has zero weight, only one result will be yielded,
458                corresponding to zero dice rolling that outcome.
459                If there are no outcomes remaining, this will be `None`.
460            * count: An `int` indicating the number of selected dice that rolled
461                the removed outcome.
462            * weight: An `int` indicating the weight of that many dice rolling
463                the removed outcome.
464        """
465
466        # The near-duplication of code with pop_max is unfortunate.
467        # However, the alternative of reversing the storage order of die_counts and truncate_min seems even worse.
468
469        truncate_min = self.truncate_min(always_tuple=True)
470        num_possible_dice = bisect.bisect_right(truncate_min,
471                                                self.die().min_outcome())
472        popped_die, outcome, single_weight = self.die()._pop_min()
473
474        if popped_die.is_empty():
475            # This is the last outcome. All dice must roll this outcome.
476            pool = Pool._pool_cached_unchecked(popped_die, count_dice=())
477            remaining_count = sum(self.count_dice())
478            weight = single_weight**num_possible_dice
479            yield pool, remaining_count, weight
480            return
481
482        # Consider various numbers of dice rolling this outcome.
483        popped_truncate_min = (popped_die.min_outcome(
484        ),) * num_possible_dice + truncate_min[num_possible_dice:]
485        popped_count_dice = self.count_dice()
486        count = 0
487
488        comb_row = icepool.math.comb_row(num_possible_dice, single_weight)
489        end_counted = self.num_dice() - self._num_drop_highest
490        for weight in comb_row[:min(num_possible_dice, end_counted)]:
491            pool = Pool._pool_cached_unchecked(popped_die,
492                                               count_dice=popped_count_dice,
493                                               truncate_min=popped_truncate_min)
494            yield pool, count, weight
495            count += popped_count_dice[0]
496            popped_truncate_min = popped_truncate_min[1:]
497            popped_count_dice = popped_count_dice[1:]
498
499        if end_counted > num_possible_dice:
500            pool = Pool._pool_cached_unchecked(popped_die,
501                                               count_dice=popped_count_dice,
502                                               truncate_min=popped_truncate_min)
503            yield pool, count, comb_row[-1]
504        else:
505            # In this case, we ran out of counted dice before running out of
506            # dice that could roll the outcome.
507            # We empty the rest of the pool immediately since no more dice can
508            # contribute counts.
509            skip_weight = 0
510            for weight in comb_row[end_counted:]:
511                skip_weight *= popped_die.denominator()
512                skip_weight += weight
513            skip_weight *= math.prod(
514                popped_die.weight_ge(min_outcome)
515                for min_outcome in truncate_min[num_possible_dice:])
516            pool = Pool._pool_cached_unchecked(popped_die, count_dice=())
517            yield pool, count, skip_weight
518
519    def _iter_pop_max(self):
520        """
521        Yields:
522            From 0 to the number of dice that can roll this outcome inclusive:
523            * pool: A `Pool` resulting from removing that many dice from
524                this `Pool`, while also removing the max outcome.
525                If there is only one outcome with weight remaining, only one
526                result will be yielded, corresponding to all dice rolling that
527                outcome.
528                If the outcome has zero weight, only one result will be yielded,
529                corresponding to zero dice rolling that outcome.
530                If there are no outcomes remaining, this will be `None`.
531            * count: An `int` indicating the number of selected dice that rolled
532                the removed outcome.
533            * weight: An `int` indicating the weight of that many dice rolling
534                the removed outcome.
535        """
536        truncate_max = self.truncate_max(always_tuple=True)
537        num_possible_dice = self.num_dice() - bisect.bisect_left(
538            truncate_max,
539            self.die().max_outcome())
540        num_unused_dice = self.num_dice() - num_possible_dice
541        popped_die, outcome, single_weight = self.die()._pop_max()
542
543        if popped_die.is_empty():
544            # This is the last outcome. All dice must roll this outcome.
545            pool = Pool._pool_cached_unchecked(popped_die, count_dice=())
546            remaining_count = sum(self.count_dice())
547            weight = single_weight**num_possible_dice
548            yield pool, remaining_count, weight
549            return
550
551        # Consider various numbers of dice rolling this outcome.
552        popped_truncate_max = truncate_max[:num_unused_dice] + (
553            popped_die.max_outcome(),) * num_possible_dice
554        popped_count_dice = self.count_dice()
555        count = 0
556
557        comb_row = icepool.math.comb_row(num_possible_dice, single_weight)
558        end_counted = self.num_dice() - self._num_drop_lowest
559        for weight in comb_row[:min(num_possible_dice, end_counted)]:
560            pool = Pool._pool_cached_unchecked(popped_die,
561                                               count_dice=popped_count_dice,
562                                               truncate_max=popped_truncate_max)
563            yield pool, count, weight
564            count += popped_count_dice[-1]
565            popped_truncate_max = popped_truncate_max[:-1]
566            popped_count_dice = popped_count_dice[:-1]
567
568        if end_counted > num_possible_dice:
569            pool = Pool._pool_cached_unchecked(popped_die,
570                                               count_dice=popped_count_dice,
571                                               truncate_max=popped_truncate_max)
572            yield pool, count, comb_row[-1]
573        else:
574            # In this case, we ran out of counted dice before running out of
575            # dice that could roll the outcome.
576            # We empty the rest of the pool immediately since no more dice can
577            # contribute counts.
578            skip_weight = 0
579            for weight in comb_row[end_counted:]:
580                skip_weight *= popped_die.denominator()
581                skip_weight += weight
582            skip_weight *= math.prod(
583                popped_die.weight_le(max_outcome)
584                for max_outcome in truncate_max[:num_unused_dice])
585            pool = Pool._pool_cached_unchecked(popped_die, count_dice=())
586            yield pool, count, skip_weight
587
588    @cached_property
589    def _popped_min(self):
590        if self.truncate_max() is not None:
591            raise ValueError('pop_min is not valid with truncate_min.')
592        return tuple(self._iter_pop_min())
593
594    def _pop_min(self):
595        """Returns a sequence of pool, count, weight corresponding to removing the min outcome.
596
597        Count and weight correspond to various numbers of dice rolling that outcome.
598        """
599        return self._popped_min
600
601    @cached_property
602    def _popped_max(self):
603        if self.truncate_min() is not None:
604            raise ValueError('pop_max is not valid with truncate_min.')
605        return tuple(self._iter_pop_max())
606
607    def _pop_max(self):
608        """Returns a sequence of pool, count, weight corresponding to removing the max outcome.
609
610        Count and weight correspond to various numbers of dice rolling that outcome.
611        """
612        return self._popped_max
613
614    def has_counted_dice(self):
615        """Returns `True` iff any of the remaining dice are counted a nonzero number of times.
616
617        This is used to skip to the base case when there are no more dice to consider.
618        """
619        return any(self.count_dice())
620
621    def sample(self):
622        """Samples a roll from this pool.
623
624        Returns:
625            A dict mapping outcomes to counts representing a single roll of this pool.
626        """
627        raw_rolls = []
628        for min_outcome, max_outcome in zip(self.truncate_min(True),
629                                            self.truncate_max(True)):
630            die = self.die().truncate(min_outcome, max_outcome)
631            raw_rolls.append(die.sample())
632        raw_rolls = sorted(raw_rolls)
633        data = defaultdict(int)
634        for roll, count in zip(raw_rolls, self.count_dice()):
635            data[roll] += count
636        return data
637
638    @cached_property
639    def _key_tuple(self):
640        return self.die().key_tuple(), self.count_dice(), self.truncate_min(
641        ), self.truncate_max()
642
643    def __eq__(self, other):
644        if not isinstance(other, Pool):
645            return False
646        return self._key_tuple == other._key_tuple
647
648    @cached_property
649    def _hash(self):
650        return hash(self._key_tuple)
651
652    def __hash__(self):
653        return self._hash
654
655    def __str__(self):
656        return '\n'.join([
657            str(self.die()),
658            str(self.count_dice()),
659            str(self.truncate_min()),
660            str(self.truncate_max())
661        ])

Represents set of (mostly) indistiguishable dice.

This should be used in conjunction with EvalPool to generate a result.

A pool is defined by:

  • A fundamental die.
  • The number of dice in the pool.
  • Which of the sorted positions are counted (possibly multiple or negative times).
  • Possibly truncating the max or min outcomes of dice in the pool (but not both) relative to the fundamental die.
Pool( die, num_dice=None, count_dice=None, *, truncate_min=None, truncate_max=None) 
198    def __new__(cls,
199                die,
200                num_dice=None,
201                count_dice=None,
202                *,
203                truncate_min=None,
204                truncate_max=None):
205        """Constructor for a pool.
206
207        You can use `die.pool(num_dice=None, ...)` for the same effect as this.
208
209        All instances are cached. The members of the actual instance may not match
210        the arguments exactly; instead, they may be optimized to values that give
211        the same result as far as `EvalPool` is concerned.
212
213        Args:
214            die: The fundamental die of the pool.
215                If outcomes are not reachable by any die due to `truncate_min` or
216                `truncate_max`, they will have 0 count. Zero-weight outcomes will
217                appear with zero weight, but can still generate nonzero counts.
218            num_dice: An `int` that sets the number of dice in the pool.
219                If not provided, the number of dice will be inferred from the other
220                arguments. If no arguments are provided at all, this defaults to 0.
221            count_dice: Determines which of the **sorted** dice will be counted,
222                and how many times. Prefer to use the `Pool`'s `[]` operator
223                after the fact rather than providing an argument here.
224                This operator is an alias for `Pool.set_count_dice()`.
225                See that method's docstring for details.
226            truncate_max: A sequence of one outcome per die in the pool.
227                That die will be truncated to that maximum outcome, with all greater
228                outcomes having 0 count. Values cannot be > the `max_outcome` of the
229                fundamental die. A pool cannot have both `truncate_min` and
230                `truncate_max`.This can be used to efficiently roll a set of mixed
231                standard dice. For example,
232                `Pool(icepool.d12, truncate_max=[6, 6, 6, 8, 8])`
233                would be a pool of 3d6 and 2d8.

235                That die will be truncated to that minimum outcome, with all lesser
236                outcomes having 0 count. Values cannot be < the `min_outcome` of the
237                fundamental die. A pool cannot have both `truncate_min` and
238                `truncate_max`.

242            result will be a `Die` rather than a `Pool`.

245            `ValueError` if arguments result in a conflicting number of dice,
246            if both `truncate_min` and `truncate_max` are provided,
247            or if truncation would produce an empty die.
248        """

251

253                                           truncate_max)
254
255        if convert_to_die:
256            return self.eval(lambda state, outcome, count: outcome
257                             if count else state)
258        else:
259            return self

Constructor for a pool.

You can use die.pool(num_dice=None, ...) for the same effect as this.

All instances are cached. The members of the actual instance may not match the arguments exactly; instead, they may be optimized to values that give the same result as far as EvalPool is concerned.

Args
  • die: The fundamental die of the pool. If outcomes are not reachable by any die due to truncate_min or truncate_max, they will have 0 count. Zero-weight outcomes will appear with zero weight, but can still generate nonzero counts.
  • num_dice: An int that sets the number of dice in the pool. If not provided, the number of dice will be inferred from the other arguments. If no arguments are provided at all, this defaults to 0.
  • count_dice: Determines which of the sorted dice will be counted, and how many times. Prefer to use the Pool's [] operator after the fact rather than providing an argument here. This operator is an alias for Pool.set_count_dice(). See that method's docstring for details.
  • truncate_max: A sequence of one outcome per die in the pool. That die will be truncated to that maximum outcome, with all greater outcomes having 0 count. Values cannot be > the max_outcome of the fundamental die. A pool cannot have both truncate_min and truncate_max.This can be used to efficiently roll a set of mixed standard dice. For example, Pool(icepool.d12, truncate_max=[6, 6, 6, 8, 8]) would be a pool of 3d6 and 2d8.
  • truncate_min: A sequence of one outcome per die in the pool. That die will be truncated to that minimum outcome, with all lesser outcomes having 0 count. Values cannot be < the min_outcome of the fundamental die. A pool cannot have both truncate_min and truncate_max.
Returns

A Pool instance. If count_dice is a single int index, the result will be a Die rather than a Pool.

Raises
  • ValueError if arguments result in a conflicting number of dice,
  • if both truncate_min and truncate_max are provided,
  • or if truncation would produce an empty die.

def set_count_dice(self, count_dice) 
305    def set_count_dice(self, count_dice):
306        """Returns a pool with the selected dice counted.
307
308        You can use `pool[count_dice]` for the same effect as this method.
309
310        The dice are sorted in ascending order for this purpose,
311        regardless of which order the outcomes are evaluated in.
312
313        This is always an absolute selection on all `num_dice`,
314        not a relative selection on already-selected dice,
315        which would be ambiguous in the presence of multiple or negative counts.
316
317        For example, here are some ways of selecting the two highest dice out of 5:
318
319        * `pool[3:5]`
320        * `pool[3:]`
321        * `pool[-2:]`
322        * `pool[..., 1, 1]`
323
324        These will also select the two highest dice out of 5, and will also
325        resize the pool to 5 dice first:
326
327        * `pool[3::5]`
328        * `pool[3:5:5]`
329        * `pool[-2::5]`
330        * `pool[0, 0, 0, 1, 1]`
331
332        These will count the highest as a positive and the lowest as a negative:
333
334        * `pool[-1, 0, 0, 0, 1]`
335        * `pool[-1, ..., 1]`
336
337        Args:
338            `None`: All dice will be counted once.
339            An `int`. This will count only the die at the specified index (once).
340                In this case, the result will be a die, not a pool.
341            A `slice`. The selected dice are counted once each.
342                If provided, the third argument resizes the pool,
343                rather than being a step,
344                but only if the pool does not have `truncate_max` or `truncate_min`.
345            A sequence of one `int`s for each die.
346                Each die is counted that many times, which could be multiple or
347                negative times. This may resize the pool, but only if the pool
348                does not have `truncate_max` or `truncate_min`.
349
350                Up to one `Ellipsis` (`...`) may be used.
351                If an `Ellipsis` is used, the size of the pool won't change. Instead:
352
353                * If `count_dice` is shorter than `num_dice`, the `Ellipsis`
354                    acts as enough zero counts to make up the difference.
355                    E.g. `pool[1, ..., 1]` on five dice would act as `pool[1, 0, 0, 0, 1]`.
356                * If `count_dice` has length equal to `num_dice`, the `Ellipsis` has no effect.
357                    E.g. `pool[1, ..., 1]` on two dice would act as `pool[1, 1]`.
358                * If `count_dice` is longer than `num_dice` and the `Ellipsis` is on one side,
359                    elements will be dropped from `count_dice` on the side with the `Ellipsis`.
360                    E.g. `pool[..., 1, 2, 3]` on two dice would act as `pool[2, 3]`.
361                * If `count_dice` is longer than `num_dice` and the `Ellipsis`
362                    is in the middle, the counts will be as the sum of two
363                    one-sided `Ellipsis`.
364                    E.g. `pool[-1, ..., 1]` acts like `[-1, ...]` plus `[..., 1]`.
365                    On a pool consisting of a single single die this would have
366                    the -1 and 1 cancel each other out.
367
368        Raises:
369            ValueError:  If `count_dice` would change the size of a pool with
370                `truncate_max` or `truncate_min`, or if more than one `Ellipsis`
371                is used.
372        """
373        convert_to_die = isinstance(count_dice, int)
374        count_dice = count_dice_tuple(self.num_dice(), count_dice)
375        if len(count_dice) != self.num_dice():
376            if self.truncate_max() is not None:
377                raise ValueError(
378                    'Cannot change the size of a pool with truncate_max.')
379            if self.truncate_min() is not None:
380                raise ValueError(
381                    'Cannot change the size of a pool with truncate_min.')
382        result = Pool._pool_cached_unchecked(self.die(),
383                                             count_dice=count_dice,
384                                             truncate_max=self.truncate_max(),
385                                             truncate_min=self.truncate_min())
386        if convert_to_die:
387            return result.eval(lambda state, outcome, count: outcome
388                               if count else state)
389        else:
390            return result

Returns a pool with the selected dice counted.

You can use pool[count_dice] for the same effect as this method.

The dice are sorted in ascending order for this purpose, regardless of which order the outcomes are evaluated in.

This is always an absolute selection on all num_dice, not a relative selection on already-selected dice, which would be ambiguous in the presence of multiple or negative counts.

For example, here are some ways of selecting the two highest dice out of 5:

  • pool[3:5]
  • pool[3:]
  • pool[-2:]
  • pool[..., 1, 1]

These will also select the two highest dice out of 5, and will also resize the pool to 5 dice first:

  • pool[3::5]
  • pool[3:5:5]
  • pool[-2::5]
  • pool[0, 0, 0, 1, 1]

These will count the highest as a positive and the lowest as a negative:

  • pool[-1, 0, 0, 0, 1]
  • pool[-1, ..., 1]
Args
  • None: All dice will be counted once.
  • An int. This will count only the die at the specified index (once). In this case, the result will be a die, not a pool.
  • A slice. The selected dice are counted once each. If provided, the third argument resizes the pool, rather than being a step, but only if the pool does not have truncate_max or truncate_min.

  • A sequence of one ints for each die. Each die is counted that many times, which could be multiple or negative times. This may resize the pool, but only if the pool does not have truncate_max or truncate_min.

    Up to one Ellipsis (...) may be used. If an Ellipsis is used, the size of the pool won't change. Instead:

    • If count_dice is shorter than num_dice, the Ellipsis acts as enough zero counts to make up the difference. E.g. pool[1, ..., 1] on five dice would act as pool[1, 0, 0, 0, 1].
    • If count_dice has length equal to num_dice, the Ellipsis has no effect. E.g. pool[1, ..., 1] on two dice would act as pool[1, 1].
    • If count_dice is longer than num_dice and the Ellipsis is on one side, elements will be dropped from count_dice on the side with the Ellipsis. E.g. pool[..., 1, 2, 3] on two dice would act as pool[2, 3].
    • If count_dice is longer than num_dice and the Ellipsis is in the middle, the counts will be as the sum of two one-sided Ellipsis. E.g. pool[-1, ..., 1] acts like [-1, ...] plus [..., 1]. On a pool consisting of a single single die this would have the -1 and 1 cancel each other out.
Raises
  • ValueError: If count_dice would change the size of a pool with truncate_max or truncate_min, or if more than one Ellipsis is used.
def truncate_min(self, always_tuple=False)

425                `tuple` even in this case.

428            return (self.die().min_outcome(),) * self.num_dice()
429        return self._truncate_min

def standard_pool(*die_sizes, count_dice=None) 
162def standard_pool(*die_sizes, count_dice=None):
163    """Creates a pool of standard dice.
164
165    For example, `standard_pool(8, 8, 6, 6, 6)` would be a pool of 2 d8s and 3 d6s.
166
167    If no die sizes are given, the pool will consist of zero d1s.
168
169    Args:
170        *die_sizes: The size of each die in the pool.
171        count_dice: Which dice will be counted, as `Pool()`.
172            As with `Pool()`, you can also use the `[]` operator after the fact.
173            For example, `standard_pool(8, 8, 6, 6, 6)[-2:]` would keep the
174            highest two dice of 2 d8s and 3 d6s.
175    """
176    if len(die_sizes) == 0:
177        return Pool(icepool.d1, num_dice=0)
178    return Pool(icepool.d(max(die_sizes)),
179                count_dice=count_dice,
180                truncate_max=die_sizes)

Creates a pool of standard dice.

For example, standard_pool(8, 8, 6, 6, 6) would be a pool of 2 d8s and 3 d6s.

If no die sizes are given, the pool will consist of zero d1s.

Args
  • *die_sizes: The size of each die in the pool.
  • count_dice: Which dice will be counted, as Pool(). As with Pool(), you can also use the [] operator after the fact. For example, standard_pool(8, 8, 6, 6, 6)[-2:] would keep the highest two dice of 2 d8s and 3 d6s.
class EvalPool(abc.ABC): 
 13class EvalPool(ABC):
 14    """An abstract, immutable, callable class for evaulating one or more `Pool`s.
 15
 16    There is one abstract method to implement: `next_state()`.
 17    This should incrementally calculate the result of the roll
 18    given one outcome at a time along with how many dice rolled that outcome.
 19    An example sequence of calls, as far as `next_state()` is concerned, is:
 20
 21    1. `state = next_state(state=None, outcome=1, count=how_many_dice_rolled_1)`
 22    2. `state = next_state(state, 2, how_many_dice_rolled_2)`
 23    3. `state = next_state(state, 3, how_many_dice_rolled_3)`
 24    4. `state = next_state(state, 4, how_many_dice_rolled_4)`
 25    5. `state = next_state(state, 5, how_many_dice_rolled_5)`
 26    6. `state = next_state(state, 6, how_many_dice_rolled_6)`
 27    7. `outcome = final_outcome(state, *pools)`
 28
 29    A few other methods can optionally be overridden to further customize behavior.
 30
 31    It is not expected that subclasses of `EvalPool`
 32    be able to handle arbitrary types or numbers of pools.
 33    Indeed, most are expected to handle only a fixed number of pools,
 34    and often even only pools with a particular type of die.
 35
 36    Instances cache all intermediate state distributions.
 37    You should therefore reuse instances when possible.
 38
 39    Instances should not be modified after construction
 40    in any way that affects the return values of these methods.
 41    Otherwise, values in the cache may be incorrect.
 42    """
 43
 44    @abstractmethod
 45    def next_state(self, state, outcome, *counts):
 46        """State transition function.
 47
 48        This should produce a state given the previous state, an outcome,
 49        and the number of dice in each pool rolling that outcome.
 50
 51        Make sure to handle the base case where `state is None`.
 52
 53        Args:
 54            state: A hashable object indicating the state before rolling the
 55                current outcome. If there was no previous outcome, this will be
 56                `None`.
 57            outcome: The current outcome.
 58                `next_state` will see all outcomes in monotonic order,
 59                either ascending or descending depending on `direction()`.
 60                If there are multiple pools, the set of outcomes is the union of
 61                the outcomes of the invididual pools.
 62            *counts: One `int` for each pool indicating how many dice in that
 63                pool rolled the current outcome. If there are multiple pools,
 64                it's possible that some outcomes will not appear in all pools.
 65                In this case, the count for the pool(s) that do not have the
 66                outcome will be 0. Zero-weight outcomes count as having that outcome.
 67
 68                Most subclasses will expect a fixed number of pools and
 69                can replace this variadic parameter with a fixed number of named
 70                parameters.
 71
 72        Returns:
 73            A hashable object indicating the next state.
 74            The special value `icepool.Reroll` can be used to immediately remove
 75            the state from consideration, effectively performing a full reroll
 76            of the pool.
 77        """
 78
 79    def final_outcome(self, final_state, *pools):
 80        """Optional function to generate a final outcome from a final state.
 81
 82        By default, the final outcome is equal to the final state.
 83        Note that `None` is not a valid outcome for a die,
 84        and if all pools consist of empty dice, the final state will be `None`.
 85        Subclasses that want to handle this case should explicitly define what
 86        happens.
 87
 88        Args:
 89            final_state: A state after all outcomes have been processed.
 90            *pools: One or more `Pool`s being evaluated.
 91                Most subclasses will expect a fixed number of pools and
 92                can replace this variadic parameter with a fixed number of named
 93                parameters.
 94
 95        Returns:
 96            A final outcome that will be used as part of constructing the result die.
 97            As usual for `Die()`, this could itself be a die or `icepool.Reroll`.
 98        """
 99        return final_state
100
101    def direction(self, *pools):
102        """Optional function to determine the direction in which `next_state()` will see outcomes.
103
104        Note that an ascending (> 0) direction is not compatible with pools with
105        `truncate_min`, and a descending (< 0) direction is not compatible with
106        pools with `truncate_max`.
107
108        The default is ascending order.
109
110        Args:
111            *pools: One or more `Pool`s being evaluated.
112                Most subclasses will expect a fixed number of pools and
113                can replace this variadic parameter with a fixed number of named
114                parameters.
115
116        Returns:
117            * > 0 if `next_state()` should always see the outcomes in ascending order.
118            * < 0 if `next_state()` should always see the outcomes in descending order.
119            * 0 if the order may be determined automatically.
120        """
121        return 1
122
123    @cached_property
124    def _cache(self):
125        """A cache of (direction, pools) -> weight distribution over states. """
126        return {}
127
128    def eval(self, *pools):
129        """Evaluates pools.
130
131        You can call the `EvalPool` object directly for the same effect,
132        e.g. `sum_pool(pool)` is an alias for `sum_pool.eval(pool)`.
133
134        Args:
135            *pools: Each element may be one of the following:
136                * A `Pool` representing possible rolls of a pool.
137                * A dict-like representing a single roll of a pool.
138                    The dict maps outcomes to counts.
139                * A sequence of outcomes representing a single roll of a pool.
140                    Outcomes are treated as having 1 count per appearance.
141                Most evaluators will expect a fixed number of pools.
142                The union of the outcomes of the pools must be totally orderable.
143                Pools with `truncate_min` and pools with `truncate_max` are not
144                compatible with each other.
145
146        Returns:
147            A die representing the distribution of the final score.
148            If all pools are `PoolRoll`s, the result is a single outcome instead.
149        """
150
151        # Convert non-pool arguments to `PoolBase`.
152        pools = [
153            pool
154            if isinstance(pool, icepool.PoolBase) else icepool.PoolRoll(pool)
155            for pool in pools
156        ]
157
158        algorithm, direction = self._select_algorithm(*pools)
159
160        dist = algorithm(direction, *pools)
161
162        if all(pool._is_single_roll() for pool in pools):
163            for state in dist.keys():
164                # Return a single outcome.
165                return state
166        else:
167            final_outcomes = []
168            final_weights = []
169            for state, weight in dist.items():
170                outcome = self.final_outcome(state, *pools)
171                if outcome is not icepool.Reroll:
172                    final_outcomes.append(outcome)
173                    final_weights.append(weight)
174
175            return icepool.Die(*final_outcomes, weights=final_weights)
176
177    __call__ = eval
178
179    def _select_algorithm(self, *pools):
180        """Selects an algorithm and iteration direction.
181
182        Returns:
183            * The algorithm to use (`_eval_internal*`).
184            * The direction in which `next_state()` sees outcomes.
185                1 for ascending and -1 for descending.
186
187        """
188        has_truncate_min = any(pool._has_truncate_min() for pool in pools)
189        has_truncate_max = any(pool._has_truncate_max() for pool in pools)
190
191        if has_truncate_min and has_truncate_max:
192            raise ValueError(
193                'A set of pools cannot be evaluated if they have both truncate_min and truncate_max.'
194            )
195
196        direction = self.direction(*pools)
197
198        if not direction:
199            if has_truncate_max:
200                direction = 1
201            elif has_truncate_min:
202                direction = -1
203            else:
204                score_ascending = sum(
205                    pool._direction_score_ascending() for pool in pools)
206                score_descending = sum(
207                    pool._direction_score_descending() for pool in pools)
208                if score_ascending < score_descending:
209                    direction = -1
210                else:
211                    direction = 1
212
213        if direction > 0 and has_truncate_min or direction < 0 and has_truncate_max:
214            # Forced onto the less-preferred algorithm.
215            return self._eval_internal_iterative, direction
216        else:
217            # Use the preferred algorithm.
218            return self._eval_internal, direction
219
220    def _eval_internal(self, direction, *pools):
221        """Internal algorithm for iterating in the more-preferred direction,
222        i.e. giving outcomes to `next_state()` from wide to narrow.
223
224        All intermediate return values are cached in the instance.
225
226        Arguments:
227            direction: The direction in which to send outcomes to `next_state()`.
228            *pools: One or more `Pool`s to evaluate.
229                This *does* change recursively.
230
231        Returns:
232            A dict `{ state : weight }` describing the probability distribution
233                over states.
234        """
235        cache_key = (direction, pools)
236        if cache_key in self._cache:
237            return self._cache[cache_key]
238
239        result = defaultdict(int)
240
241        if all(len(pool.outcomes()) == 0 for pool in pools):
242            result = {None: 1}
243        else:
244            outcome, iterators = _pop_pools(direction, pools)
245            for p in itertools.product(*iterators):
246                prev_pools, counts, weights = zip(*p)
247                prod_weight = math.prod(weights)
248                prev = self._eval_internal(direction, *prev_pools)
249                for prev_state, prev_weight in prev.items():
250                    state = self.next_state(prev_state, outcome, *counts)
251                    if state is not icepool.Reroll:
252                        result[state] += prev_weight * prod_weight
253
254        self._cache[cache_key] = result
255        return result
256
257    def _eval_internal_iterative(self, direction, *pools):
258        """Internal algorithm for iterating in the less-preferred direction,
259        i.e. giving outcomes to `next_state()` from narrow to wide.
260
261        This algorithm does not perform persistent memoization.
262        """
263        dist = defaultdict(int)
264        dist[None, pools] = 1
265        # This is only safe because all pools are guaranteed to pop outcomes at the same rate.
266        while not all(len(pool.outcomes()) == 0 for pool in pools):
267            next_dist = defaultdict(int)
268            for (prev_state, prev_pools), weight in dist.items():
269                # The direction flip here is the only purpose of this algorithm.
270                outcome, iterators = _pop_pools(-direction, prev_pools)
271                for p in itertools.product(*iterators):
272                    pools, counts, weights = zip(*p)
273                    prod_weight = math.prod(weights)
274                    state = self.next_state(prev_state, outcome, *counts)
275                    if state is not icepool.Reroll:
276                        next_dist[state, pools] += weight * prod_weight
277            dist = next_dist
278        return {state: weight for (state, _), weight in dist.items()}

An abstract, immutable, callable class for evaulating one or more Pools.

There is one abstract method to implement: next_state(). This should incrementally calculate the result of the roll given one outcome at a time along with how many dice rolled that outcome. An example sequence of calls, as far as next_state() is concerned, is:

  1. state = next_state(state=None, outcome=1, count=how_many_dice_rolled_1)
  2. state = next_state(state, 2, how_many_dice_rolled_2)
  3. state = next_state(state, 3, how_many_dice_rolled_3)
  4. state = next_state(state, 4, how_many_dice_rolled_4)
  5. state = next_state(state, 5, how_many_dice_rolled_5)
  6. state = next_state(state, 6, how_many_dice_rolled_6)
  7. outcome = final_outcome(state, *pools)

A few other methods can optionally be overridden to further customize behavior.

It is not expected that subclasses of EvalPool be able to handle arbitrary types or numbers of pools. Indeed, most are expected to handle only a fixed number of pools, and often even only pools with a particular type of die.

Instances cache all intermediate state distributions. You should therefore reuse instances when possible.

Instances should not be modified after construction in any way that affects the return values of these methods. Otherwise, values in the cache may be incorrect.

@abstractmethod
def next_state(self, state, outcome, *counts) 
44    @abstractmethod
45    def next_state(self, state, outcome, *counts):
46        """State transition function.
47
48        This should produce a state given the previous state, an outcome,
49        and the number of dice in each pool rolling that outcome.
50
51        Make sure to handle the base case where `state is None`.
52
53        Args:
54            state: A hashable object indicating the state before rolling the
55                current outcome. If there was no previous outcome, this will be
56                `None`.
57            outcome: The current outcome.
58                `next_state` will see all outcomes in monotonic order,
59                either ascending or descending depending on `direction()`.
60                If there are multiple pools, the set of outcomes is the union of
61                the outcomes of the invididual pools.
62            *counts: One `int` for each pool indicating how many dice in that
63                pool rolled the current outcome. If there are multiple pools,
64                it's possible that some outcomes will not appear in all pools.
65                In this case, the count for the pool(s) that do not have the
66                outcome will be 0. Zero-weight outcomes count as having that outcome.
67
68                Most subclasses will expect a fixed number of pools and
69                can replace this variadic parameter with a fixed number of named
70                parameters.
71
72        Returns:
73            A hashable object indicating the next state.
74            The special value `icepool.Reroll` can be used to immediately remove
75            the state from consideration, effectively performing a full reroll
76            of the pool.
77        """

State transition function.

This should produce a state given the previous state, an outcome, and the number of dice in each pool rolling that outcome.

Make sure to handle the base case where state is None.

Args
  • state: A hashable object indicating the state before rolling the current outcome. If there was no previous outcome, this will be None.
  • outcome: The current outcome. next_state will see all outcomes in monotonic order, either ascending or descending depending on direction(). If there are multiple pools, the set of outcomes is the union of the outcomes of the invididual pools.

  • *counts: One int for each pool indicating how many dice in that pool rolled the current outcome. If there are multiple pools, it's possible that some outcomes will not appear in all pools. In this case, the count for the pool(s) that do not have the outcome will be 0. Zero-weight outcomes count as having that outcome.

    Most subclasses will expect a fixed number of pools and can replace this variadic parameter with a fixed number of named parameters.

Returns

A hashable object indicating the next state. The special value icepool.Reroll can be used to immediately remove the state from consideration, effectively performing a full reroll of the pool.

96            A final outcome that will be used as part of constructing the result die.
97            As usual for `Die()`, this could itself be a die or `icepool.Reroll`.
98        """
